title: What you should do before you "push" your changes - python

cover_slide_data.heading: What you should do before "push" your changes - Python
What you should do before "push" your changes - Python

published_attributes.title: Course overview
published_attributes.serialized_body:
In this course you will learn about different methods of a code formatting and actually why this is import for us as developers.

The presentation consists of lessons about Python linters and formatters like Black, Flake8 or Isort and about general rules of a code formatting. At the end you will find a short quiz.

I hope everything you will learn during this course will be useful in your future job as a Python Developer. Good luck!

published_attributes.title: Style is important!
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Of course logic of our code is important but it also has to look neat and tidy!

Here you will learn about tools that will make your code more beautiful and your life easier ;)

blocks.text: Of course logic of our code is important but it also has to look neat and tidy!
Here you will learn about tools that will make your code more beautiful and your life easier ;)

published_attributes.title: PEP 8
published_attributes.serialized_body: PEP 8 is the document that states all the rules how to write python code. This is our source of style and thanks to it pythonic code can be consistent. But after all we are software developers, so let’s try to automate the process of checking our code with PEP 8 rules!

blocks.text: PEP 8 is the document that states all the rules how to write python code. This is our source of style and thanks to it pythonic code can be consistent. But after all we are software developers, so let’s try to automate the process of checking our code with PEP 8 rules!

published_attributes.title: Linters and formatters
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Linter - is a static code analysis tool used to flag programming errors, bugs, stylistic errors, and suspicious constructs

Formatter - a computer program used for formatting

blocks.text: Linter - is a static code analysis tool used to flag programming errors, bugs, stylistic errors, and suspicious constructs
Formatter - a computer program used for formatting

published_attributes.title: Black
published_attributes.serialized_body:
And here comes black - your best friend when writing python code!

Black is a formatter that automagically will fix your formatting problems.

P.S. If you've ever used yapf just forget it. Black is a better option.

blocks.text: And here comes black - your best friend when writing python code!
Black is a formatter that automagically will fix your formatting problems.
P.S. If you've ever used yapf just forget it. Black is a better option.

published_attributes.serialized_body: There is an example of the same code, in the "raw" version on the left and in the formatted version on the right - using Black.

published_attributes.title: Black - how to example
published_attributes.serialized_body:
If you just want to ask if everything is ok, you can do it.

black --check {source_file_or_directory}

And just ask black nicely to fix it for you

black {source_file_or_directory}

blocks.text: If you just want to ask if everything is ok, you can do it.

And just ask black nicely to fix it for you

published_attributes.title: Black configuration
published_attributes.serialized_body:
You are the king and can change the rules!

You can use a packages management tool e.g. Poetry to adjust Black to your needs and preferences. Exclude/ include specific files, directories or specify the required line length.

blocks.text: You are the king and can change the rules!
You can use a packages management tool e.g. Poetry to adjust Black to your needs and preferences. Exclude/ include specific files, directories or specify the required line length.

published_attributes.title: Flake8
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Flake8 is a linter composed out of these tools:

  • PyFlakes
  • pycodestyle
  • Ned Batchelder’s McCabe script

PyFlakes - A simple program which checks Python source files for errors. Pyflakes analyzes programs and detects various errors. It works by parsing the source file, not importing it, so it is safe to use on modules with side effects. It’s also much faster.

pycodestyle - a tool used to check your Python code against some of the style conventions in PEP 8.

Ned Batchelder’s McCabe script - checks cyclomatic complexity.

(Cyclomatic complexity- is a software metric used to indicate the complexity of a program)

blocks.text: Flake8 is a linter composed out of these tools:
PyFlakes
pycodestyle
Ned Batchelder’s McCabe script

pycodestyle - a tool used to check your Python code against some of the style conventions in PEP 8.
Ned Batchelder’s McCabe script - checks cyclomatic complexity.
(Cyclomatic complexity-  is a software metric used to indicate the complexity of a program)

published_attributes.title: Flake8 - example
published_attributes.serialized_body: Flake is your friend, but it isn’t as nice as black. It just yells at you when you make mistakes (doesn't fix them) - but that’s also good and useful :)

blocks.text: Flake is your friend, but it isn’t as nice as black. It just yells at you when you make mistakes (doesn't fix them) - but that’s also good and useful :)

published_attributes.title: Flake8 error codes
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Every error code has a meaning :)

We don’t have to remember them but it’s handy to have the cheatsheet around.

blocks.text: Every error code has a meaning :)
We don’t have to remember them but it’s handy to have the cheatsheet around.

published_attributes.serialized_body: We can disable flake checking for a particular line using # noqa

published_attributes.title: Flake customization
published_attributes.serialized_body: We can customize flake behaviour using a config file. We can ignore particular rules, exclude files or set how complex we want our code to be!

blocks.text: We can customize flake behaviour using a config file. We can ignore particular rules, exclude files or set how complex we want our code to be!

published_attributes.title: Black vs Flake8
published_attributes.serialized_body:
When your configuration is not correct, Flake can mark Black corrections as errors!

Important! Sometimes we have to setup config files for black and flake so they don’t collide. 

But when they work together properly configured, Black and Flake are a powerful companion in our development work.

blocks.text: When your configuration is not correct, Flake can mark Black corrections as errors!
Important! Sometimes we have to setup config files for black and flake so they don’t collide.
But when they work together properly configured, Black and Flake are a powerful companion in our development work.

published_attributes.title: Pre-commit
published_attributes.serialized_body:
Pre-commit is a tool that runs scripts before it lets you commit them to git.

It’s a gatekeeper of good practices. 

Example configuration in pre-commit-config.yml file, based on one of the internal projects:

This configuration sets tools: Black and Flake, which will run when you commit your changes.

To install this configuration, run:

pre-commit install

blocks.text: Pre-commit is a tool that runs scripts before it lets you commit them to git.
It’s a gatekeeper of good practices.
Example configuration in pre-commit-config.yml file, based on one of the internal projects:
This configuration sets tools: Black and Flake, which will run when you commit your changes.
To install this configuration, run:
pre-commit install

published_attributes.title: Example pre-commit
published_attributes.serialized_body: As you can see, pre-commit reformats your files and checks if everything is correct before letting you to commit your changes to git.

blocks.text: As you can see, pre-commit reformats your files and checks if everything is correct before letting you to commit your changes to git.

published_attributes.title: Isort
published_attributes.serialized_body:
There is one more tool, which is worth to mention: Isort.

Isort is a Python utility / library to sort imports alphabetically, and automatically separate into sections and by type.

Although, black takes care of imports, you can step up your importing game using isort

blocks.text: There is one more tool, which is worth to mention: Isort.
Isort is a Python utility / library to sort imports alphabetically, and automatically separate into sections and by type.
Although, black takes care of imports, you can step up your importing game using isort
